js.user
Class JsXMLHttpRequest

java.lang.Object
  js.Disposable
      js.Var<JsObject>
          js.core.JsObject
              js.dom.DOM.XMLHttpRequest.Prototype
                  js.user.JsXMLHttpRequest
All Implemented Interfaces:
ObjectLike
public class JsXMLHttpRequest
extends DOM.XMLHttpRequest.Prototype

An opaque class representing JavaScript client-side objects of the global JsClient.XMLHttpRequest class.

A JsXMLHttpRequest object allows client-side JavaScript to issue HTTP requests and receive responses, which need not be XML, from web servers.

JsXMLHttpRequest is quite portable and well supported by all modern browsers. The only browser dependency involves the creation of an JsXMLHttpRequest object. In IE, you must use the constructor of the IE-specific JsClient.ActiveXObject: DOM.ActiveXObject.create(String).

Once a JsXMLHttpRequest object has been created, you typically use it like this:

  1. Call open(String, String, Boolean, String, String) to specify the URL and method (usually "GET" or "POST") for the request. When you call open(String, String, Boolean, String, String), you also specify whether you want the request to be synchronous or asynchronous.
  2. If you specified an asynchronous request, set the onreadystatechange property to the function that will be notified of the progress of the request.
  3. Call setRequestHeader(String, String), if needed, to specify additional request parameters
  4. Call send(Object) to send the request to the web server. If it is a POST request, you may also pass a request body to this method. If you specify a synchronous request in your call to open(String, String, Boolean, String, String), the send(Object) method blocks until the response is complete and readyState is LOADED. Otherwise, your onreadystatechange event handler function must wait until the readyState property reaches LOADED (or at least RECEIVING).
  5. Once send(Object) has returned for synchronous requests, or readyState has reached LOADED for asynchronous requests, you can use the server's response. First, check the status code to ensure that the request was successful. If so, use getResponseHeader(String) or getAllResponseHeaders() to retrieve values from the response header, and use the responseText or responseXML properties to obtain the response body.

JsXMLHttpRequest objects have not been standardized, but work on a standard has begun at the W3C.

Author:
J.J.Liu (Jianjun Liu) at http://www.jscripter.org
JavaScript:
Opaque types can be resolved but no class objects for them can be generated into the target codes. Re-compilers must exit with error on the operations of accessing that kind of class objects. The checkcast operation to the class literal of this interface must be ignored and instanceof to it always true.

A legal value for the readyState representing the initial state that the JsXMLHttpRequest object has just been created or has been reset with the abort() method.

public static final short LOADED
A legal value for the readyState indicating that the HTTP response has been fully received.

Since:
1.0
See Also:
Constant Field Values

readyState

public static final Value.Number.Member readyState

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsXMLHttpRequest object refers to a read-only integer value specifying the state of the HTTP request. The value begins at UNINITIALIZED or 0 when the JsXMLHttpRequest object is first created and increases to LOADED or 4 when the complete HTTP response has been received. The five states are UNINITIALIZED, OPEN, SENT, RECEIVING and LOADED, each having an informal name associated with it.

The value of the property never decreases, unless the abort() or open(String, String, Boolean, String, String) method is called on a request that is already in progress. Every time the value of the property increases, the onreadystatechange event handler is triggered.

Since:
1.0
See Also:
UNINITIALIZED, OPEN, SENT, RECEIVING, LOADED, onreadystatechange, abort(), open(String, String), open(String, String, Boolean), open(String, String, Boolean, String, String)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

responseText

public static final Value.String.Member responseText

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsXMLHttpRequest object refers to a read-only string value specifying the body of the response, excluding headers, that has been received from the server so far, or the empty string if no data has been received yet. If readyState is less than RECEIVING, the property is the empty string. When readyState is RECEIVING, the property returns whatever portion of the response has been received so far. If readyState is LOADED, the property holds the complete body of the response.

If the response includes headers that specify a character encoding for the body, that encoding is used. Otherwise, the Unicode UTF-8 encoding is assumed.

Since:
1.0
See Also:
UNINITIALIZED, OPEN, SENT, RECEIVING, LOADED
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

status

public static final Value.Number.Member status

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsXMLHttpRequest object refers to a read-only integer value specifying the HTTP status code returned by the server, such as 200 for success and 404 for "Not Found" errors. Reading this property when readyState is less than RECEIVING causes an error.

Since:
1.0
See Also:
UNINITIALIZED, OPEN, SENT, RECEIVING, LOADED
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

statusText

public static final Value.String.Member statusText

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsXMLHttpRequest object refers to a read-only string value specifying the HTTP status code of the request by name rather than by number. That is, it is "OK" when status is 200 and "Not Found" when status is 404. As with the status property, reading the property when readyState is less than RECEIVING causes an error.

Since:
1.0
See Also:
UNINITIALIZED, OPEN, SENT, RECEIVING, LOADED
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

responseXML

public static final JsDocument.Member responseXML

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsXMLHttpRequest object is a read-only reference to the response to the request, parsed as XML and returned as a Document object. The property will be null unless all three of the following conditions are true:

  • readyState is LOADED.
  • The response includes a Content-Type header of "text/xml", "application/xml", or anything ending with "+xml" to indicate that the response is an XML document.
  • The response body consists of well-formed XML mark-up that can be parsed without errors.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

onreadystatechange

public static final JsFunction.Member<?> onreadystatechange

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsXMLHttpRequest object is a reference to the event handler function invoked each time the readyState property changes. It may also be invoked multiple times while readyState is RECEIVING.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

var

public final JsDocument var(JsDocument.Member r)

abort

public void abort()

Cancels the current request, closing connections and stopping any pending network activity.

This method resets the JsXMLHttpRequest object to a readyState of UNINITIALIZED and aborts any pending network activity. You might call this method, for example, if a request has taken too long, and the response is no longer necessary.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

getAllResponseHeaders

public java.lang.String getAllResponseHeaders()

Returns the HTTP response headers as an unparsed string.

Returns:
null if readyState is less than RECEIVING; Otherwise, it returns all HTTP response headers, but not the status line, sent by the server. The headers are returned as a single string, with one header per line. Lines are delimited by "\r\n" line terminators.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

getResponseHeader

public java.lang.String getResponseHeader(java.lang.String header)

Returns the value of a named HTTP response header.

Parameters:
header - The name of the HTTP response header whose value is to be returned. the header name may be specified using any case, as the comparison to response headers is case-insensitive.
Returns:
The value of the named HTTP response header, or the empty string if no such header was received or if readyState is less than RECEIVING. If more than one header with the specified name is received, the values of those headers are concatenated and returned, using a comma and space as the delimiter.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
getResponseHeader(StringLike)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

Returns:

open

public void open(java.lang.String method,
                 java.lang.String url)

Initializes HTTP request parameters, such as the URL and HTTP method, but does not send the request.

This method initializes request parameters for later use by the send(Object) method. It sets readyState to OPEN, deletes any previously specified request headers and previously received response headers, and sets the responseText, responseXML, status, and statusText properties to their default values. It is safe to call this method when readyState is UNINITIALIZED {when the JsXMLHttpRequest object is just created or after a call to abort()), and when readyState is LOADED, (after a response has been received). The behavior of this method is unspecified when it is called from any other state.

Other than storing request parameters for use by send(Object) and resetting the JsXMLHttpRequest object for reuse, this method has no other behavior. In particular, note that implementations do not typically open a network connection to the web server when this method is called.

Parameters:
method - The HTTP method to be used for the request. Reliably implemented values include "GET", "POST", and "HEAD". Implementations may also support other methods as well.
url - The URL that is the subject of the request. Most browsers impose a same-origin security policy and require that this URL have the same host name and port as the document that contains the script. Relative URLs are resolved in the normal way, using the URL of the document that contains the script.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
open(String, String, Boolean), open(String, String, Boolean, String, String), send(Object)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

open

public void open(java.lang.String method,
                 java.lang.String url,
                 java.lang.Boolean async)

Initializes HTTP request parameters, such as the URL and HTTP method, but does not send the request.

This method initializes request parameters for later use by the send(Object) method. It sets readyState to OPEN, deletes any previously specified request headers and previously received response headers, and sets the responseText, responseXML, status, and statusText properties to their default values. It is safe to call this method when readyState is UNINITIALIZED {when the JsXMLHttpRequest object is just created or after a call to abort()), and when readyState is LOADED, (after a response has been received). The behavior of this method is unspecified when it is called from any other state.

Other than storing request parameters for use by send(Object) and resetting the JsXMLHttpRequest object for reuse, this method has no other behavior. In particular, note that implementations do not typically open a network connection to the web server when this method is called.

Parameters:
method - The HTTP method to be used for the request. Reliably implemented values include "GET", "POST", and "HEAD". Implementations may also support other methods as well.
url - The URL that is the subject of the request. Most browsers impose a same-origin security policy and require that this URL have the same host name and port as the document that contains the script. Relative URLs are resolved in the normal way, using the URL of the document that contains the script.
async - Specifies whether the request should be performed asynchronously or not. If this argument is false, the request is synchronous, and a subsequent call to send(Object) will block until the response is fully received. If this argument is true or is undefined, the request is asynchronous, and an onreadystatechange event handler is typically required.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
open(String, String), open(String, String, Boolean, String, String), send(Object)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

open

public void open(java.lang.String method,
                 java.lang.String url,
                 java.lang.Boolean async,
                 java.lang.String username,
                 java.lang.String password)

Initializes HTTP request parameters, such as the URL and HTTP method, but does not send the request.

This method initializes request parameters for later use by the send(Object) method. It sets readyState to OPEN, deletes any previously specified request headers and previously received response headers, and sets the responseText, responseXML, status, and statusText properties to their default values. It is safe to call this method when readyState is UNINITIALIZED {when the JsXMLHttpRequest object is just created or after a call to abort()), and when readyState is LOADED, (after a response has been received). The behavior of this method is unspecified when it is called from any other state.

Other than storing request parameters for use by send(Object) and resetting the JsXMLHttpRequest object for reuse, this method has no other behavior. In particular, note that implementations do not typically open a network connection to the web server when this method is called.

Parameters:
method - The HTTP method to be used for the request. Reliably implemented values include "GET", "POST", and "HEAD". Implementations may also support other methods as well.
url - The URL that is the subject of the request. Most browsers impose a same-origin security policy and require that this URL have the same host name and port as the document that contains the script. Relative URLs are resolved in the normal way, using the URL of the document that contains the script.
async - Specifies whether the request should be performed asynchronously or not. If this argument is false, the request is synchronous, and a subsequent call to send(Object) will block until the response is fully received. If this argument is true or is undefined, the request is asynchronous, and an onreadystatechange event handler is typically required.
username - An optional argument specifying authorization user name for use with URLs that require authorization. If specified, it overrides the user name specified in the URL itself.
password - An optional argument specifying authorization password for use with URLs that require authorization. If specified, it overrides the password specified in the URL itself.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
open(String, String), open(String, String, Boolean), send(Object)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

send

public void send(java.lang.Object body)

Sends the HTTP request, using parameters passed to the open(String, String, Boolean, String, String) method and an optional request body passed to this method.

This method causes an HTTP request to be issued. If there has been no previous call to open(String, String, Boolean), or, more generally, if readyState is not OPEN, this method throws an error. Otherwise, it issues an HTTP request that consists of:

  • The HTTP method, URL, and authorization credentials (if any) specified in the previous call to open(String, String, Boolean, String, String).
  • The request headers, if any, specified by previous calls to setRequestHeader(String, String).
  • The body argument passed to this method.
Once the request has been issued, this method sets readyState to SENT and triggers the onreadystatechange event handler.

If the async argument to the previous call to open(String, String, Boolean, String, String) was false, this method blocks and does not return until readyState is LOADED and the server's response has been fully received. Otherwise, if the async argument is true or if that argument is undefined, this method returns immediately, and the server's response is processed on a background thread.

If the server responds with an HTTP redirect, this method or the background thread follow the redirect automatically. When all HTTP response headers have been received, this method or the background thread sets readyState to RECEIVING and triggers the onreadystatechange event handler. If the response is long, this method or the background thread may trigger the onreadystatechange more than once while in state RECEIVING. This can serve as a download progress indicator. Finally, when the response is complete, this method or the background thread sets readyState to LOADED and triggers the event handler one last time.

Parameters:
body - If the HTTP method specified by the call to open(String, String, Boolean, String, String) is "POST" or "PUT", this argument specifies the body of the request, as a string or JsDocument object, or null if no body is necessary. For any other method, this argument is unused and should be null, but some implementations do not allow you to omit this argument.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
open(String, String), open(String, String, Boolean), open(String, String, Boolean, String, String)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

setRequestHeader

public void setRequestHeader(java.lang.String name,
                             java.lang.String value)

Sets or adds an HTTP request header to an open but unsent request.

This method specifies an HTTP request header that should be included in the request issued by a subsequent call to send(Object). This method may be called only when readyState is OPEN, that is, after a call to open(String, String, Boolean, String, String) but before a call to send(Object).

If a header with the specified name has already been specified, the new value for that header is the previously specified value, plus a comma, a space, and the value specified in this call.

If the call to open(String, String, Boolean, String, String) specifies authorization credentials, JsClient.XMLHttpRequest automatically sends an appropriate Authorization request header. You can append to this header with this method, however. Similarly, if the web browser has stored cookies associated with the URL passed to open(String, String, Boolean, String, String), appropriate Cookie or Cookie2 headers are automatically included with the request. You can append additional cookies to these headers by calling this method. JsClient.XMLHttpRequest may also provide a default value for the User-Agent header. If it does this, any value you specify for that header is appended to the default value.

Some request headers are automatically set by the JsClient.XMLHttpRequest for conformance to the HTTP protocol and may not be set with this method. These include proxy-related headers as well as the following:

  • Host
  • Connection
  • Keep-Alive
  • Accept-Charset
  • Accept-Encoding
  • If-Modified-Since
  • If-None-Match
  • If-Range
  • Range

Parameters:
name - The name of the header to be set. This argument should not contain spaces, colons, linefeeds, or newlines.
value - The value for the header. This argument should not contain linefeeds or newlines.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.
